WorkItem.Description:
I have created a brush for the AlternatingRowBackground Property:
    <LinearGradientBrush x:Key="AlternatingDataGridRowBackground" StartPoint="0,0" EndPoint="0,1">
        <GradientStop Offset="0" Color="#FFEBEBEB"/>
    </LinearGradientBrush>
Then in the RowStyle property I add a IsMouseOver trigger in order ton change the brush:
    <Style x:Key="DataGridRowStyle" TargetType="{x:Type tlkCtrl:DataGridRow}">
        <Setter Property="SnapsToDevicePixels" Value="True"/>
        <Setter Property="Foreground" Value="#FF333333"/>
        <Style.Triggers>
             <Trigger Property="IsMouseOver" Value="True">
                <Setter Property="Background">
                    <Setter.Value>
                        <LinearGradientBrush StartPoint="0,0" EndPoint="0,1">
                            <GradientStop Color="#FFfffce5" Offset="0"/>
                            <GradientStop Color="#FFffeca0" Offset="0.49900001287460327"/>
                            <GradientStop Color="#FFffd641" Offset="0.5"/>
                            <GradientStop Color="#FFffdf63" Offset="1"/>
                        </LinearGradientBrush>
                    </Setter.Value>
                </Setter>
                <Setter Property="BorderBrush" Value="#FFC0A776"/>
            </Trigger>
        </Style.Triggers>
    </Style>
 
Whenever the mouse is over an alternated row the style doesn´t change.
WorkItem.Summary: DatagridRow IsMouseOver Trigger Doesn´t work with an AlternatingRowBackground Brush

Comments.Message: The AlternatingRowBackground property value is transferred from the DataGrid to the DataGridRow and ends up with a higher priority than the style value. To workaround the issue, don't use AlternatingRowBackground and instead create a trigger that sets the Background to the alternate color when AlternationIndex is equal to 1. If you place this trigger before the IsMouseOver trigger, then the mouse over trigger should have a higher priority than the alternate color trigger. You will also have the opportunity now to specify an alternate mouse over color.

Now I've got the mouseover to function proper like ben carter said.

I came up with this in my resources.xaml
...
    <Style TargetType="{x:Type dg:DataGridRow}" >
        <Style.Triggers>
            <Trigger Property="dg:DataGridRow.AlternationIndex" Value="1">
                <Setter Property="Background" Value="Lavender" />
            </Trigger>
            <Trigger Property="dg:DataGridRow.IsMouseOver" Value="True">
                <Setter Property="Background" Value="CadetBlue" />
                <Setter Property="Foreground" Value="#e2fce2" />
            </Trigger>
        </Style.Triggers>
    </Style>
